December 30, 1979: Fiction
JAILBIRD, by Kurt Vonnegut. (Delacorte/Seymour Lawrence, $9.95.) From World
War II to Watergate: one man's fumbling career.
TRIPLE, by Ken Follett. (Arbor House, $10.95.) Power play between intelligence
agents in the Middle East.
THE ESTABLISHMENT, by Howard Fast. (Houghton Mifflin, $11.95.) The
Lavettes of "The Immigrants" and "Second Generation" survive and prosper in
post-World War II America.
MEMORIES OF ANOTHER DAY, by Harold Robbins. (Simon & Schuster, $10.95.)
Saga of the American labor movement.
THE EXECUTIONER'S SONG, by Norman Mailler. (Little, Brown, $16.95.) The life
and death of Gary Gilmore.
SMILEY'S PEOPLE, by John le Carr√©. (Knopf, $10.95.) The great British spy has
a final confrontation with his Russian counterpart.
THE LAST ENCHANTMENT, by Mary Stewart. (Morrow, $11.95.) Further
adventures of King Arthur.
THE GREEN RIPPER, by John D. MacDonald. (Lippincott, $9.95.) Travis McGee
finds love, loses love.
THE DEAD ZONE, by Stephen King. (Viking, $11.95.) Johnny Smith can see the
future and no one wants to listen.
THE TOP OF THE HILL, by Irwin Shaw. (Delacorte, $8.95.) A jaded New Yorker
courts danger in New England.
THERE'S NO SUCH PLACE AS FAR AWAY, by Richard Bach. (Delacorte/
Eleanor Friede, $6.95.) Homilies about love and friendship in the spirit of
"Jonathan Livingston Seagull."
SOPHIE'S CHOICE, by William Styron. (Random House, $12.95.) The nature of
evil explored through the story of two doomed lovers.
THE MATARESE CIRCLE, by Robert Ludlum. (Richard Marek, $12.50.) The top
American and Soviet agents save Western civilization.
WAR AND REMEMBRANCE, by Herman Wouk. (Little, Brown, $15.) The Henry
family of "The Winds of War" during World War II.
THE THIRD WORLD WAR: August 1985, by General Sir John Hackett and Other
Top-ranking NATO Generals and Advisors. (Macmillian, $12.95.) A history of the
global war to come.
December 30, 1979
Non-Fiction
THE BRETHREN, by Bob Woodward and Scott Armstrong. (Simon & Schuster,
$13.95.) Inside the Supreme Court.
AUNT ERMA'S COPE BOOK, by Erma Bombeck. (McGraw-Hill, $8.95.) How to
get from Monday to Friday... in 12 days.
WHITE HOUSE YEARS, by Henry Kissinger. (Little, Brown, $22.50.) President
Nixon's foreign affairs advisor tells his own story, 1968-73.
JAMES HERRIOT'S YORKSHIRE, by James Herriot. (St. Martin's Press, $15.) An
illustrated tour of the veterinarian's homeland.
CRUEL SHOES, by Steve Martin. (Putnam's, $8.95.) Zany satire by a young
television comedian.
THE COMPLETE SCARSDALE MEDICAL DIET, by Herman Tarnower, M.D. and
Samm Sinclair Baker. (Rawson, Wade, $7.95.) A plan to lose up to 20 pounds in
14 days.
THE AMERICANS, by Alistair Cooke. (Knopf, $10.95.) What Alistair Cooke told his
British radio listeners about us, 1969-79.
THE RIGHT STUFF, by Tom Wolfe. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $12.95.) Project
Mercury, America's first manned space program, recalled in high style.
HOW TO PROSPER DURING THE COMING BAD YEARS, by Howard J. Ruff.
(Times Books, $8.95.) Personal investment guide.
SERPENTINE, by Thomas Thompson. (Doubleday, $12.95.) A quintessential con
man leaves a trail of murder and robbery around the globe.
ANATOMY OF AN ILLNESS, by Norman Cousins. (Norton, $9.95.) A patient's
account of his successful fight against a serious disease.
CONNECTIONS, by James Burke. (Little, Brown, $17.50.) How we reached this
technological age; tie-in to the PBS series.
SECOND WIND, by Bill Russell and Taylor Branch. (Random House, $9.95.)
Memoirs of the basketball player, a self-described "opinionated man."
WITH NO APOLOGIES, by Barry M. Goldwater. (Morrow, $12.95.) Memoirs of a
conservative U.S. Senator.
RESTORING THE AMERICAN DREAM, by Robert J. Ringer. (Harper & Row,
$12.50.) A polemic against big government.
